content: norse copyright © general hogbuffer 2015 this design takes its main inspiration from the traditional nordic knitting design a lot of the shap- ing that occurs in traditional yoked sweaters is hidden in the designs of the yoke so i employed the same principles to incorporate the increases needed for a classic strong heel into the stranded border designs please make sure you read all of the pattern before you begin and pay attention to the suggestions at the end if you would like to make changes to the design size this design uses 72 sts over stranded knitting for the leg and 64 sts over plain stocking st on the foot this works out to about 7 1/2 inches circumference of the relaxed unstretched sock this could be amended by working to a different gauge by changing the needle size if needed material yarn a koigu kpm in col 0000 natural 1 skein = 50 gr yarn b koigu kpppm in col p642 111 red 2 skeins = 100gr gauge on my sample i was getting 33 sts x 45 row over 4 inches of plain stocking stitch with the smaller needles and 36 sts x 43 row over 4 inches of stranded stocking stitch with the bigger size needles but take this as a guide line only make sure that the sock fits you well and that you are happy with the drape of the fabric you are creating first of all needle size you will need needles in two consecutive sizes the size that you would be most happy to knit your chosen yarn with in a normal sock i used 2 5 mm and then one size bigger i used 2 75 mm there is scope here to adjust to your personal preference and to fine-tune the size of the finished sock use what works best for you i have written the instructions for circular needles and/or magic loop if you prefer to work with dpn s please note that needle 1 and needle 2 may mean different things for you other than that there should be no issues further requirements - tapestry needle - stitch markers although you could do it without if they irritate you - some extra double pointed needles may come handy for the heel turn and finishing the toe norse page 2 cuff with the smaller needle and yarn a using your favourite cast-on method cast on 72 sts and close to a round taking care not to twist the cast-on work k2 p2 rib for as many rounds as you would like your cuff to be i did 24 rounds for my sam- ple k 5 plain rounds leg change to bigger needles and introduce yarn b and work row 1 46 of the leg chart the section outlined in blue shows the repeat that will fit 6 times around your leg throughout the whole of the leg and the heel the beginning of the round markes the centre back
